So far that's the most irritating thing I've encountered while using the Sony Bloggie, but here is a more in-depth run-down of my pros and cons:The Good:- Breath-taking picture quality. Anybody can make their own Earth documentary with this thing, the picture is SO clear. It's glossy and detailed and just utterly mind-blowing.- Touch Screen. this will actually appear on a "bad" list as well for zooming, but for messing around with settings and options the touch screen is very handy.- Still pictures. The Bloggie is an upgrade for me from my previous video camera, the Flip MinoHD, and so I was quite thrilled to see that Sony's camera can take phenomenal still shots in quality as high as 12mp. There's also a self timer function, which is always handy.- Tri-pod slot. I'm pretty sure all camera have these, but it's nice to know this one does too. I bought a little Flip Video Tripod and it screws in nicely and keeps the camera steady in just about any location.-Pop-out USB. These make me nervous, but they certainly are handy. The USB connector pops out of the camera itself so it's always ready for connecting to a computer. No worries about losing wires or forgetting to bring them.-HDMI output. This is amazingly handy for a quick connection to your 1080p television. All you need is a Gold-Plated Advanced High Speed HDMI Cable with Ethernet (6 feet) and you can connect it to your TV through an HDMI slot. This is a great way to actually see what you recorded instead of loading it onto a computer and then viewing it. Plus, the video looks A M A Z I N G on a 1080p television screen.- Easy function. Anybody can use this camera, it's very simple and bare bones. You point and shoot. There's nothing really fancy about it. For some people that's probably a down side, but since I'm not a professional movie director I think it's kinda nice.-Memory. 8gb is a shockingly large amount of space and provides enough room for a good two hours of true 1080p footage, even more if you choose to film in lower HD (720p) - up to 4 hours, they claim.-Battery Life. Even after playing around with it for hours, recording most of that time, the battery is still going so I can't complain about how long the juice lasts when you start on a full tank.The Bad/Mediocre:The Autofocus. Pretty much everytime you move the camera it's going to need to do a little autofocusing. Depending on the depth of the new object it's looking at, this could take half a second or three or four or more. It is beyond frustrating. Not just because for a time the picture is fuzzy, but because you have to sit and watch the camera think and then watch this zoom in/out business while it regains focus. Once it has focus, however, it REALLY has focus and every little detail sparkles with high definition. So if you plan on recording something with the camera remaining very still it should be perfect... otherwise, be prepared for some focusing issues.Sound quality. I wouldn't call the sound "bad" and maybe "mediocre" is even a little harsh because it is good given the size and shape of the camera, but when you compare it to the picture quality it's not so magnificent. I know the purpose of this camera is convenience, no ordinary person wants to attach big Hollywood microphones to a little camera, but just be aware that some sounds may be a little high pitched and some will be soft while others startlingly loud. Nevertheless, I think it's very satisfactory for home use.Zoom. Pretty much worthless, I would not recommend using the zoom feature because it distorts the picture and isn't really that impressive. As you can tell from my video, once I zoom is everything gets very fuzzy. Additionally, it's very difficult to smoothly zoom with the touch screen feature because it either under-reacts or over-reacts to touch, and you have to jeopardize the steadiness of the camera to do it.Software. The software it comes with is not bad for beginner film editors, but for anybody looking to do a little more I would suggest sticking to whatever software you are already familiar with.--------Overall, for $150 this is a fantastic latest-greatest gadget in the realm of home video cameras. The picture quality is so so so incredibly amazing that watching it actually makes it feel like you are back in the moment. The autofocus is irksome and with the way home video cameras continue to evolve and upgrade, there May be better option out there or in the near future, but to be honest it isn't THAT annoying. After getting used to it for a while I managed to understand how to move the camera around so the autofocus didn't intrude too much, and if you're not interested in being overly professional it's hardly a worry.

Reviews.Title: Great product !
Reviews.Author: michele harman
Reviews.Content: I was really impressed how small it was .Feels good in the hands ,great video quality.We have a Flip HD Ultra and I would say that the Sony Bloggie blows it out the water.

Reviews.Title: Depends of Price
Reviews.Author: Dan D.
Reviews.Content: I use this as a video camcorder/camera I can easily keep in my pocket to capture the unexpected.  Its small size makes this ideal.  If I know I will need a camera, I go with another bulkier model.In perfect condition (well lit room) the video is unrivaled.  Darker conditions degrade quality.Software for Sony Bloggie is not good, not even adequate.  I imagine most people spend 2-3 hours frustrated before going back to iPhoto or Picasa. It is Mac compatible.If there is background noise this camera will pick it up.Autofocus is not perfect, it will go in and out.Also, this could be a plus or minus.  Close ups are great with this bloggie but you need distance to record a whole person top to bottom.I bought a refurb for $87 and I am happy.  If I paid $180 for new, I would be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Incredible quality when it is able to focus
Reviews.Author: acetto
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for my wife for her birthday.  After a few days of using it, we were amazed.  It is a very sleek, cool looking camera and is capable of giving very good quality videos.  However, after using it for about a month, we wound up taking it back and getting a flip.  Here are my findings:1. ERGONOMICS.  This camera is very slim and light.  I didn't have much trouble with it, but my wife hated it.  It is sleek and very cool looking, but she just hated the way it felt in her hand.  She constantly complained that she couldn't handle it well.  I guess it was too slim for her to get a good hold on it.  I'll admit the flip is easier to hold being quite a bit fatter.  I kinda figured the whole point of getting this type of camera was to have something compact and sleek, but you might want to consider what your preference is.  Again, I didn't have a problem with holding this thing and using it.2. LIGHT.  It does fiarly well with handling light.  It can shoot in the sun beautifully.  In an average lit room with incandescent or fluorescent lighting, it did well with a slight loss of color in dimly lit rooms.  With a backlit subject, like my kid running around the living room with a window behind him with sun coming in, it was horrible, which is not too unusual for most cameras in this price range.3. FOCUS.  The first day we got this camera, we were pleased to see the green box show up around my son's face.  It had identified his face and was trying to focus on him.  However, after a few days of use, we realized that box didn't come up too often, and dissappeared quickly when it did show up.  As soon as my son would move, it would focus on something else, then go completely out of focus and have great difficulty getting back in focus.  We tried and tried, and found this to be the norm.  After about a month with this camera we gave up.  This was the reason we eventually took this camera back and got something else.Basically, if you are shooting video of something that doesn't move and is at least descently lit, this is an awesome camera.  I plugged the bloggie into my 46" sony bravia and was amazed (Costco sells it with the HDMI cable included).  The video quality is far superior to the flip.  The video quality can rival some much more expensive camcorders, when it is in focus.  However, if you are shooting video of anything that may move, this camera just isn't that practiacal.Although I was very interested in looking at the Kodak playsport, my wife wanted the flip and we never looked at the Kodak.  I suspect the Kodak may have been our best option in this class of camera.

Reviews.Title: Excellent with three very annoying traits -UPDATED
Reviews.Author: DirtRider "I like to play in the dirt"
Reviews.Content: The video with the stabilizer is fantastic however, it takes a while for it to focus which is annoying. That's #1It takes great pictures especially at close range!It looks and feels great. Having a touch screen is fantastic. It's easy to use.It records sound very well however, because of the way it's designed, I tend to hold it where the microphone slots are and that muffles the sound. I got used to not doing that but it does happen from time to time. You hear your hand shifting around it. That's #2When you record the video, it will set either landscape or portrait depending on how you are holding it which can get annoying.  It should have a setting for a default set up which never changes. Maybe there is one but I can't find it. That's #3As a device on a tripod outdoors in bright light, it's wonderful but that's not what I need it for. I need it to record things like dirt bike riding, zip-lining, races, etc and it just does not cut it. It also really lacks in low light situation.I am going to order the Kodak Zi8 which I've read is leagues beyond.*Update:  I did the firmware update for this model and it has made the camera focusing problem much better. Upping it to four stars!

Reviews.Title: Solid product - easy to use
Reviews.Author: Soar
Reviews.Content: This is one of my devices I smile whenever I use.  I charged it and was using it immediately.ProsI have primarily used the bloggie for short videos and find it completely simple and intuitive to use.  The commands and icons on the touch screen are straight forward and I figured them out by just clicking on them.  I like the touch screen, it has a similar responsiveness to smart phones.Starting up and taking a video or a picture is very easy.  The bloggie boots up quickly so if I want to snap a picture or start a video, I can do it in seconds.  That is big.I like the fact that I can be doing a video and can snap a picture while videoing.ConsI have noticed that the focusing on the bloggie can be slow (as a number of reviewers have bashed the unit for).  This is noticeable to me but not a show stopper.As obvious as it should be it took a few times for this to click with me... the orientation of the image is based on how I am holding the bloggie.  If I am holding it vertically (which for me is the most comfortable hand position) it is taking a vertical wide-screen (9:16 instead of 16:9)...  if I turn the bloggie on the side it takes a normal wide-screen.  I haven't dug into the settings yet to see if I can change this, wouldn't surprise me if I could be changed there are plenty of settings with this item.At one point, the screen froze up and by holding the power button for 5 or so seconds, it shut down and restarted fine.SummaryI've tried to list positives and negatives and have deducted a star for negatives.  Overall, I like the bloggie and enjoy using it.

Reviews.Title: Good video camera for daytime use
Reviews.Author: PJTX
Reviews.Content: I got the bloggie just this week and am pleased with its performance so far, except for a few quirks. Firstly, the on screen zoom feature isn't very easy to use and is very jerky. It might be a better idea to have physical zoom toggle thats more like a real camera. Secondly, I don't understand why the bloggie does not have a built in flash for the camera, even most cell phones have a flash built in these days. My last complaint about the Bloggie is the software - it's a bit clunky. I found it easier and faster to use just Windows 7 to extract the videos.Now to the things that I think the bloggie does well. It takes some really good video, especially if you are in a well lighted setting. The still picture quality is pretty good as well.I would recommend this camera if you like taking a lot of video clips of kids playing at home etc. I was doing a lot of that on my phone but the video quality left much to be desired. With the bloggie at hand, i can now capture all those fun activities in HD !

Reviews.Title: 4 stars for video, 3 for still pictures.
Reviews.Author: Angela Streiff
Reviews.Content: The good:Touch  screen is high quality. Not overly sensitive where your accidentally  pressing commands when you don't mean to. But definitely does what you want it to when you do want it to do something.Menu is extremely user friendly and easy to learn. Within 10 minutes of playing around with it, you can totally understand how to use each of the features and feel comfortable with them.Ability to take both pictures and videos with the camera in either the horizontal or vertical position.  Simply turn the camera and it automatically changes modes.Sleek, compact design with a touch screen that does a good job of minimizing finger smudges. Small enough to slide into the smallest of pockets, yet takes high quality videos like it's larger counterparts.Separate buttons for picture and video recording. The recording button in the large circular button in the center of the Bloggie, the button to snap a picture sits on the side of the camera. This helps a lot to make sure your in the mode you want to be, and not taking video when your trying to take a still picture.Turns on fast! The Bloggie is on in just a few seconds and ready to take pictures and video.  This makes it  much more convenient for recording those unexpected moments.The not so good:The Bloggie does not do well taking digital pictures in low light. In a typical indoor setting with household lights, it's still too dark sometimes. I find myself wishing it had a flash all the time while taking pictures. You seem to need either natural light or florescent light to take a decent still photo. The recording feature definitely seems to do better in low light situations.A little slow to focus in recording mode. You can definitely see the Bloggie trying to focus as your recording.  The better the lighting conditions, the less the focusing seems to be an issue. We took a video while out ice fishing and when going from inside an ice shack (dim light) to outside on a very bright and sunny day, there was a significant focusing time for the camera. Seemed to take about 5+ seconds before the camera was able to come out of the blur and focus on the lake.Final thoughts:While it's not perfect, it's a great little camera. I own this and the Kodak Play Touch (also takes, pictures and records) , and the while the Bloggie's picture quality in low light is not the best, in total it still takes better photos, as the image stabilization in the Kodak is not nearly as good. I end up with a lot more blurry photos with my Kodak, where the Bloggie takes clear photos that can come out a little dark in low light. Also the menus in the Bloggie are much more friendly and the video I have taken with the Bloggie has been brighter and cleaner looking than with my Kodak. So far, I am happier with my Bloggie.

Reviews.Title: Excellent !
Reviews.Author: Serge C. Bakmeijer
Reviews.Content: Normally i buy stuff off amazon, but right before xmas i saw this camera in an electronic store and fell in love with it.I was hunting down a FLIP. went to that store to buy the flip. nothing else, untill i saw the bloggie touch.i didnt buy anything went home, on amazon, read some reviews. next day went back out got the bloggie.some reviewers mention focus problem. true, that problem exists. it's not a problem if you use your brain cells,.. the way i see it is.. you move the camera around too much, it will try to focus on various type of things. is it a bad thing? id say i would rather have the option that the camera is constantly trying to find the best focus.so what i personally do with it is, i keep it steady. video's i take are taken in a vehicle. so my outside view is changing and moving while the dashboard is steady. so this dynamic focussing is excellent.also i have to say, for the price, i think the quality of the picture is superb. i love the 720p@60hz. sound is great. and i have applied the new firmware 1.05 that addresses the crazy focussing problem.i mean it completely depends on how u use the camera. absolutely no regrets. I LOVE IT.and by the way did i mention its the cadillac of small hd camcorders. this thing is beautiful.

Reviews.Title: I wanted to like this as well...
Reviews.Author: W. Bell
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera from BestBuy when my Kodak PlaySport simply died (it doesn't turn on any more - previous night okay, next day - dead...)I love the form factor of the Bloggie; it was so small it could fit in my hard shell glasses case! Never had a camera that could do that before! So it was really easy to just grab and go - anyone seeing it would just think it was a cell phone.I also agree with other reviews about the grainy images when in low light conditions.  In my opinion, the videos also looked a bit "soft"; not much sharpness in recorded details.  At times I believe the antishake processing was noticeable in some of the recording as well (subtle shifting of the subjects within the frame for example.)The issue that made me return the camera is the fact when you turn the camera vertically, the camera records in a vertical mode WASTING all the space around the video with a black border!  There isn't even an option to turn this off!On playback you get this terribly small "postage stamp" of your recording in the middle surrounded by a sea of black border!Ultimately I found myself holding the camera horizontally pressing record to START the recording and then rotating the camera back vertically, which would keep the horizontal orientation for the remainder of the recording. (I then rotate my videos back in post using my editing software.)Didn't have this problem with the PlaySport which maintains a horizontal orientation.For now, I've sort of settled on a Canon 4000is which is blazing fast at snapping pictures (8.4 fps in the burst mode, nearly 4 fps in Program mode which is amazing to me coming from other Canon pocket cams that could barely snap at 2 fps.  Video is 1280x720 30 fps but I'd still prefer 60 fps.  Low light is the best I've had to date using a Canon snap camera; 85+% of my snaps come out clear with this camera compared to all my older ones!)I'd still like a pocket camcorder so I plan on evaluating the Sanyo VPC-PD2BK later this week - to perhaps go along with my 4000is which is a definite keeper for me.I still somewhat like the Bloggie though, it's a sleek, great gift camera for perhaps someone that rarely takes pictures / video and not looking for as much perfection as possible from the camera they use.With a software update to lock the video orientation (or remove that vertical mode altogether), I could see using the camera again for myself or perhaps recommending it more to friends and family.

Reviews.Title: Amazing
Reviews.Author: Benjamin
Reviews.Content: Id like to have ten of these. It's the best point and shoot camera you can get for the price ($70 when I bought it) very few settings, but it's fine. It can record at 720p 60fps, 1080p 30fps, 720p 30fps, and it's camera can shoot at 12, 8, and 2 megapixels.

Reviews.Title: Good, inexpensive little camera!
Reviews.Author: Gary W. Barker Jr. "G.W."
Reviews.Content: I like to Bloggie Touch.  For about $70 I got a really great product.  There are some Cons, but I believe the Pros outweigh them.  The video is here [...]

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the price!
Reviews.Author: Brent
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera last year when it was around $170, I wish I would have waited to get it at the price it is now but I really like this camera!I keep hearing a lot of not so good reviews on it and I can't understand why people don't like it.Pros:-The quality of the video is fantastic in most lighting conditions.-Can take 12 mp pictures even while taking video.-Has three options to record in such 720p (30fps), 720p (60fps), and 1080p (30fps)-Its format is mp4 which can be opened by many types of programs such as quicktime.Cons:-Only has digital zoom and doesn't look great when you zoom:/-The lens does sometimes take a while to adjust to whatever you're looking at, never bothered me though.-It doesn't do very good in low light.Overall I highly recommend this camcorder to anyone, I love my bloogie and the quality it serves so don't listen to the bad reviews because some people are really anal when it comes to video cameras but if you like good quality and a smooth picture then look no further:D

Reviews.Title: Does what it's supposed to do
Reviews.Author: Lawrence M. Russo II "Stargazer"
Reviews.Content: Although I could use my iPhone for quick recording etc I wanted a device dedicated for this purpose. The Sony is small very quick to turn on and start recording. The touch screen needs some refinement. It's somewhat unresponsive to touch but that may be a design feature as not to accidentally tap screen while recording? Anyway out of the box it's really very simple to use and build quality is typical Sony standards...

Reviews.Title: Works for me!
Reviews.Author: Evelyn "Dweenaleena"
Reviews.Content: Simple and easy to use. Sufficiently good quality for my purpose, which is recording and reviewing practice sessions in between lessons. A little grainy in low light situations.Very easy to download. I decided not to use the bloggie software, having my own video editing/organizational software that I'm already comfortable with. So I just dump the files into a folder on my desktop and then format the bloggie to empty the memory out and get it ready to use again. It charges while plugged into the powered-up lappy.All in all, works great for me!

Reviews.Title: GREAT QUALITY!
Reviews.Author: Sean
Reviews.Content: This compact HD video recorder is awesome... it is SO SMALL! The HD quality is awesome as well.  It powers up very fast so you don't have to keep it on all day waiting for your shot.  The auto focus works well in most cases, and it is very easy to see if the focus is off and you can readjust it.  The touch screen is also a nice touch.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera/camcorder for preserving/sharing memories and travels
Reviews.Author: Pravin G "pravin g."
Reviews.Content: Bought this for an extended vacation trip to Europe rather than lug a handycam around.POSITIVES:Size and weight are OH SO GOOD for travel as is the touchscreen (like a mobile phone).  Connects to laptop through built in USB for viewing and charging.  Software is pre-loaded and self-installs.Took pictures and video indoors and outdoors on rainy, cloudy and sunny days. Convenient. Zoom works well for stills.Played back very well on both my laptop and, even, more vivid, on 1080p TV with the HDMI connection.Stills grainy through HDMI, but perfect through USB connection.Very compact and lightweight.Pretty quick charge through USB connected to laptop or car charger.Easy to adjust video and still image quality with several options available, right through the touchscreen.NEGATIVES:Does not perform too well under poor lighting conditions.No flash.  Requires special HDMI cable (standard Type A to Type C cable) to hook-up to HDTV.Takes a second or so to auto focus when moving across objects far and near. Improved auto focus with Firmware upgrade.Not so great zooming while shooting for focus. Touchscreen not the most convenient for zooming either while shooting. Best NOT to zoom while shooting video.Upgraded to v1.05 which improves touchscreen and autofocus, BUT NOISY shooting video in 1080p due to "constant autofocus adjustment". No problems shooting 720p, still providing excellent video quality through HDMI.SHARING WHILE TRAVELING:Simple YouTube and Facebook uploads through included Bloggie software.RECOMMENDATION:Case to protect camera.  Screen protector for LCD screen.  Car USB charger for extended road trips so camera is ALWAYS fully charged.OVERALL SUMMARY:Clearly a nice little camera for preserving and sharing memories. Great for travel. Not for professional quality photography, but what do you expect for the price and convenience.

Reviews.Title: Decent Product with HORRIBLE SOFTWARE!!
Reviews.Author: Brent C. Mills "FaultyDrive Admin"
Reviews.Content: When I got my Bloggie HD Touch 8GB, I only had a few minor issues with it.  *The focus was sluggish and inaccurate.  *The touch interface was irritatingly inaccurate.Both of these issues were fixed with the 1.5 firmware update which can be downloaded from Sony's website for free.  With those issues out of the way, I tried to install the Bloggie software on my laptop.  I'm running Windows 7 Ultimate 32 bit (a supported OS) and had nothing but trouble installing this software.When the Setup_Bloggie.exe application was run, I encountered Javascript errors which prevented me from installing the Bloggie software on my computer.  Being a systems administrator, I tracked down the javascript file that was being run by this program and attempted to bypass the Setup_Bloggie.exe program altogether.  I found the install program and went to run it manually.  The install only got about 60% of the way before failing because it was missing files.  I ran back through the code and found that a few files seemed to be missing.At this point I contacted Sony's customer support (people you would expect to be at least moderately technical) to see if they could send me a link to a new version of the Bloggie Software.  After an hour and a half with customer service, I had lost my patience and received no help at all.  I would go 15 minutes without any kind of response (This was over their online support chat client) and in the end he kept telling me to read the manual (which simply told me to run Setup_Bloggie.exe).  When I finally asked to speak to a manager or an engineer, he told me I should contact a different department.  Rather than transfer me himself, he wanted me to call back later.After a little while longer, I did manage to install the Bloggie Software on my own, but still cannot get it to function correctly.  If you receive error messages when attempting to install the software, try the following:Please remember that I am a very experienced user.  I would NOT recommend that anyone try this if they are not comfortable getting their hands dirty so to speak.  Instead, I would recommend that we all push for Sony to release some software that works.  I am not responsible for anything that may happen to your computer if you attempt this procedure.  1.) Go to the "Start" Menu and open the "Control Panel".  2.) Click on "Folder Options".  3.) In the new window, click on the "View" tab along the top bar.  4.) Scroll down until you see "Hidden Files and Folders".  Click "Show Hidden Files, Folders, and Drives" underneath this item.  5.) Click "Apply"  (Leave this window open.  It is a good idea to click "Don't Show Hidden Files, Folders, or Drives" as soon as you finish this process.  6.) Open "My Computer" or "Computer".  7.) Find "Bloggie Software (J:)" along the left hand bar.  8.) Open the "conf" folder.  9.) Scroll down until you see "Setup" or "Setup.exe".  10.) Right-click on this item and select "Troubleshoot Compatibility"  11.) In the new window that opens, click "Start the Program...".This will install the program.  However, even after installing and updating the software, the software will STILL not recognize my Bloggie.  I still cannot synch my camera with my computer.Note that the updates require this same procedure, but you first have to find the updated software files (The same files that Sony would not provide me earlier) in your C:\Users\USERNAME\AppData\Local\Temp\" directory.  Mine was titled 1293649297.  Finding it was fun.As for the camera itself, I found it to be a bit lacking in color saturation and contrast.  Everything seemed a bit flat.  Then again, I couldn't get Sony's software to work properly, so there may be something in there that can correct these issues.All in all, I like the Bloggie HD for what it is.  It's a (relatively) cheap, pocket video camera.  I wouldn't use it to shoot anything serious, but it's great for those times when your boss takes you to a "unique" restaurant and the food is still moving.  Assuming Sony ever fixes their software issues, this could be a great product.

Reviews.Title: Sony Booger
Reviews.Author: DancingLacey
Reviews.Content: Purchased this Sony Bloogie about 2weeks ago. This way I had time to really use it and get back to you. The style is pretty nice, liked it very much as compared to others in this category. Screen size is the best, very large and clear. The size & weight is perfect, it feels and weighs just like my LG cell phone. Video quality is pretty darn nice, very clear with alot of light needed because this bloggie has no flash or light of its own. Sound quality is very low. When you replay you can barely hear sound. Once its connect to your HDTV you can raise the volume, so problem fixed there. The picture quality connected to the Sony Bravia TV is excellent. Connecting to YouTube and Facebook is easy and effortless, but try sending messages via the Sony software provided and thats where you might encounter a variety of errors and space issues. Basically you probably won't be able to send the videos you took via email to say your Mom or Friends. Contacted Sony Support(their help desk) and SonyListens(Twitter)and no one can figure out why it won't work using their OWN software! Hope this review helps.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful for a novice, but limited without a flash
Reviews.Author: a
Reviews.Content: I did not have the technical problems that some of the other reviewers had with this product.  For me, it DID work right out of the box, and I've not have any trouble taking stills or HD video in the two weeks I've used it.  It's a great little device with one big problem, in my opinion.  Its lack of a flash is such a ridiculous oversight, I felt compelled to read others' reviews just to be certain I wasn't crazy.  Others have pointed this out too.I had been using a years-old Sony Cybershot, and I would occasionally take stills (with flash) on my Sony HDD camcorder.  I had hoped that the Bloggie Touch would replace them both as a small and stylish alternative, giving me the ability to shoot HD video from a device the size of my iPhone.  And outdoors, it's remarkably convenient.  Whereas on a vacation to, say, Walt Disney World, I would have the bulky Cybershot on a strap on one arm with the camcorder in its own bag on the other, the Bloggie Touch fits in the smallest pocket of my cargo shorts and basically does everything that both of these devices do.  Ah, but if I ever find myself taking pictures in low light, forget it.  The video turns out better than the stills, but again, I think it's silly that a device this nifty could not have a built-in flash like most smart phones.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful design with very poor image quality
Reviews.Author: PeterB10021
Reviews.Content: The design, style and weight of the Bloggie made it hard to resist.  The streamlined features and simple to use settings found on the LCD panel were appealing concepts to me as well -- initially.For still pictures, I experienced the following problems.  The shutter (somewhat hard to find unless you are looking at the camera instead of at the subject of your picture) needs to be depressed halfway and slowly for the autofocus to work properly.  It is a fixed lens so my expectations were not high to begin with.  While this shutter is a common feature, on the Bloggie it takes practice.  It remains a very slow shutter process and it compromises the ultimate image.  The Bloggie does not perform in bright daylight -- the pictures have too much contrast and they are never sharp -- even at 12 megapixels.  In lower light, the colors quickly shift and the autofocus suffers even more.  A Bloggie's output appears to never be in focus --  even in regular interior commercial lighting.The videos are slightly better than the still pictures but they still fall short of any HD video camera of any size that I have seen.  The Bloggie is also able to take still pictures while it is filming a video.  The pictures are not worse than if they would have been taken on their own and the same is true of the video. This might be the only positive comments that I can make about the Bloggie's video and picture output.  The inferior pictures and videos are no more inferior when the Bloggie records them both simultaneously.The Sony software for the Bloggie (MAC version) that I installed and used is acceptable.  However, because the Bloggie will work with iPhoto, I gave up on the Bloggie software after 2-3 days.  The Sony software only has a fraction of the features that iPhoto has.I have always owned Sony products from many different categories.  I have had more Sony digital cameras and camcorders than I have any other Sony device.  If anything, I had hoped that my favorable bias would overcome my disappointment with Bloggie but it did not.  The Bloggie's output was inferior and always unusable.  I am sorry that i bought it.

Reviews.Title: A value choice, but recognize the limitations
Reviews.Author: Gaz Rendar
Reviews.Content: The Sony Bloggie Touch has some neat features at a good price that makes it an interesting choice when compared to it's obvious competitors.I'll start by saying the packaging of the Bloggie is pretty cool.  It comes in a nice, compact box that you'll want to keep for long term storage of the device.  The Bloggie itself is also very svelte, small, and stylish.  It's smaller than most smartphones, but has a very usable 3" touch screen on the back.  There is a faux wood pattern that adorns the front of the device, a record button on the back, and a power and camera button on the right side.  There is an HDMI port with a cover on the left side, and a flip out USB stick on the bottom.  Simple layout for simple, intuitive use.Touching on the screen brings up the 4 different menu options, which are rather limited.  The first menu lets you pick image sizes.  You can choose 720p 30frames per second, 720p 60fps, or 1080p 30fps.  The camera setting lets you choose 2, 8, or 12 megapixels.  Note that the 12MP images are 4:3 ratio.  There is a menu that provides a 2 or 10 second timer. The general setting menu allows you to set the date, HDMI settings, format the device, set language, and turn off the beeps.  The last menu is a PLAY button that showcases all of your media.  There is also a Wide - Tight digital zoom slider that's always present on-screen.  The screen itself does an admirable job of displaying your pictures and movies.  The screen isn't super responsive like say, an iPhone, but with the simple menu options it's never a hindrance.The software comes pre-loaded on the Bloggie device.  Turn the Bloggie on and plug it into your computer's USB port and you're ready to install.  The software is barebones simple.  You can view the media on your Bloggie and choose to import it to your computer, or you can automatically upload it to your YouTube and social media websites.  There's not much else going on here.  But there is one problem.  The software loads a Bloggie Watcher utility into your taskbar that boots when windows starts up.  There is an option to not have the Watcher Utility load when windows starts, but on 2 different Vista machines selecting this option had no effect.  The Watcher still loads when I start windows.  I had to goto my msconfig file to block it.  Don't know if this is specific to Vista, but it is annoying.  I shouldn't have to have even more mini-software programs bog down my start up time. Vista is bad enough as it is.As for the movie making?  Well, it's average.  The Bloggie has an autofocusing mechanism that can't be adjusted.  Here's where the video settings come into play.  The Bloggie Touch can take 1080p video at 30fps, which is better than the usual 720p that most competitor cameras max out at.  Unfortunately, you have to temper your excitement over the 1080p.  At 1080p, in medium to ideal lighting, from 4-8 feet away, the Bloggie performs well.  It can autofocus quick enough as long as you hold the camera steady.  If you're trying to focus back and forth between things 6 - 25 feet away, the Bloggie will struggle a bit.  Same if you're in less than medium lighting conditions.  I did find that the Bloggie performs noticeably better when it's at 720p / 60fps.  The video on this setting is clear and buttery smooth even if you're panning your shot at a normal speed.  It does a better job autofocusing at 720p 60fps as well.  Not awesome, but better. When you're in close-to-ideal lighting conditions, you can take some pretty good video under this setting.  Of course, this somewhat negates the distinguishing 1080p feature that separates this device from the others out there.What's it all mean for you?  Well, if you want a device that can take competitive 720p video with a smooth 60fps rate and you occasionally want to take 1080p video with a very steady hand, or tripod, in ideal lighting conditions, in an area where you don't changes in depth of field focus (phew...), then the Bloggie will work well for you.  Otherwise you may want to go with a competitor device that has better image stabilization.  And if you want to be able to take versatile videos in a variety of settings, then the Bloggie Touch and Flips of the world are not going to work for you; you'll need to pony up an extra $100-300 to get a decent camcorder with optical zoom and stabilizers.  But if you're looking for a good value choice, and recognize the video limitations, the Bloggie can work for you.  I'd like to give it 3.5 stars because it's cost is attractive, but with Amazon's system I have to round up to 4.

Reviews.Title: Slick, ok HD in reasonable light, but -
Reviews.Author: G. Traveis "Prod Design Engineer"
Reviews.Content: It's a nice, touchy device. It actually does macro focus! However it's very noisy in low light.  Even in normal light, it's exposure settings change very quickly and drastically.  I can tolerate focus flubs much more than having the exposure fluctuating 2-3 fStops in about as much time as it takes to "two to three f-stops". When panning, there's a really odd rotational jitter that must have something to do with image stabilization.  Too bad that some of these focus/exposure functions aren't settable in the camera's setup menu.  Exposure, focus and orientation (portrait/landscape) lock would fix a LOT of these issues.  Also, this camera in a soft case, or no case, tends to turn itself on very easily - a great way to kill the battery.I WANTED to like this camera more than I do.I think I'll try to find a small digital camera that can do 1080P with continuous focus and better noise specs.

Reviews.Title: great pocket camcorder
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Alpha Maven"
Reviews.Content: there's mentioned of poor auto-focus but compared to other pocket camcorders this one performs about the same.  Most of the time there's no need to change the focus of the subjects.  this by far has a better video quality than the latest Flip Ultra or any pocket camcorders in the market now.  A really big problem is when you want to record in widescreen mode you have to hold the camera on the side unlike the Flip or conventional pocket camcorders which you can hold upright.  I believe Sony wanted the consumer to take advantage of its 3" screen while filming that way but they should enable the option to record while holding the camera upright as it feels more sturdy.  overall like others this pocket camcorder has the best picture quality in the market right now with some flaws.

Reviews.Title: Breezy, easy to use
Reviews.Author: Eric San Juan
Reviews.Content: It didn't take long to become enamored with the Bloggie's easy of use and comfortable functionality. Once I had it powered up I was quickly navigating menus and taking video with nary a glance at the instruction manual.The touchscreen is responsive and the menus easy to navigate. All functions are icon driven. It's fairly simple to go through your videos, play them back, and set videos to auto-upload to sites like YouTube and Facebook when they're dumped to your computer.Taking video is a cinch. Press the red button. Boom, now you're filming. The Bloggie will automatically switch between landscape and vertical depending on how you're holding the device. This isn't ideal, as ergonomically it's easiest to hold the Bloggie upright -- which is also how you hold it for vertically aligned videos when most people will want landscape. But that's a minor gripe. By and large, it's painfully easy to shoot video. Even grandma can do it.Video quality is surprisingly good. Very sharp, even when played back on my plasma. The autofocus isn't always perfect, so keep your eyes peeled for that, but the issue didn't come up frequently. Video quality is a big step up from digital cameras that also do video or your typical iPhone/Blackberry.Dumping the stuff to your PC is a breeze. A USP connection swings out, you plug it in (with cord adapter), and you're dropping videos in no time.The Bloggie is small, thinner than an iPhone, narrower, but a bit longer. Fits comfortably in your hand and will slide into any pocket. It doesn't come with any sort of portable case or covering, though, so be careful with it.The only question I'm left with is, who is this product's target audience? In a world where every smart phone has most of these same capabilities built in (albeit at much lower quality), most digital cameras do video, and hand-held video cameras aren't much more expensive, who is this aimed for?Well, if you're the target market, you'll know. And I can certainly recommend a Bloggie.EDIT: So a month later, the Bloggie abruptly died on me. No reason, it just stopped working. The screen went black and all functions ceased operating. The unit remains on, however, and heated up. Then it died. Won't power on, PC won't recognize it, nothing. Disappointing.EDIT2: After sitting for just over a week, unable to get power or retain a charge, the Bloggie mysteriously began working again. No problems since. I don't know how to explain it.

Reviews.Title: Good Buy
Reviews.Author: Dan Cooksey "corralesdan"
Reviews.Content: I bought the Bloggie Touch as an upgrade from my Flip video and I haven't been disappointed.  It's easy and intuitive to use.  The video quality is very good.  The picture quality is very good.  The only thing I'm not crazy about is the USB connection - it's a little loose.  Other than that I'm satisfied.

Reviews.Title: DON'T BUY THIS CAMERA- MULTIPLE REASONS
Reviews.Author: James Ross
Reviews.Content: I've used the Flip camera for years and I had really high hopes when I changed and bought this camera.  I really wanted a camera that would record in 1080.PROBLEMS:1)the 1080P in playback was very jumpy2) the touchscreen was awful.  For example, when I touched an icon in the bottom right, the camera would select the icon on the top right.  I have small fingers, so that wasn't the problem.  I took videos on it for a week and it took me over 15 minutes to individually delete 10 videos because of the crappy touch screen.3) The software that it installs on your computer is really buggy.  Half of the time I would plug the camera in to view my footage, all of the thumbnail icons were black.4) THE WORST PROBLEM IS THAT WHEN YOU DO WATCH YOUR RECORDING, THERE IS A CONSTANT CLICKING NOISE!  I have no idea what would cause this, but that fact alone would be enough to not recommend this camera.Summary: Stay away from even considering this camera.  If you want a small pocket camcorder, go with a Flip.

Reviews.Title: ok for the cost
Reviews.Author: Ronald G. Chimelak
Reviews.Content: nice & compact & easy to use. doesn't take very good pics in dim light 'though due to no flash.

Reviews.Title: WOW!!! What a Camera
Reviews.Author: Sylvia A. Germany
Reviews.Content: I love the camera; especially the fact that I can also use it to record events.  The convenience of being able to carry it in by purse wherever I go is a plus.  I never have to miss a photo moment.Thanks...

Reviews.Title: satisfied
Reviews.Author: bev
Reviews.Content: A nice replacement for the flip.  Which they took batteries for our school rather then a charge.  The quality is good and easy to use.

Reviews.Title: GREAT PRICE
Reviews.Author: Foxi687
Reviews.Content: BOUGHT THIS AS A GIFT FOR MY BF'S BIRTHDAY BCUZ HE HAS TO SELL HIS A WHILE BACK SO I WAS ABLE TO AFFORD TO SURPRISE HIM WITH A NEW ONE, HE WAS THRILLED! GLAD THIS SELLER HAD IT AT THE TIME :)

Reviews.Author: Elliot
Reviews.Content: I have to say this little guy is great! Fits in your pocket and starts up quickly. We bought it for a trip to Disney World with our kids and it recorded great. Only problem would be the Auto focus and low light recording isn't great.

Reviews.Title: can anyone tell me why this is listed as  "4 hour"
Reviews.Author: TL "tlc"
Reviews.Content: I bought this Bloggie for one reason - to be able to video tape the 3 hour workshops where I work and my old flip camera could only do 120 minutes. Since this one is listed as a  "Sony Bloggie Touch Camera, 4-Hour" I thought it would be the perfect solution but the battery only lasts for 120 minutes the same as the old flip which is very misleading. Also annoying is that will will automatically shut off after about 30 minutes so it's necessary to keep turing it back on (and then having a bunch of shorter video clips). This is a good looking video camera but it really doesn't work well and offer very little flexibility for individual needs.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful camera
Reviews.Author: Joyleen "Piano lady"
Reviews.Content: I love this camera and the videos it produces are very neat.  Only thing I do not like about it is the clips only go 29 minutes.  It has 4 hour storage, but you can't run something for 4 hours.  In recording a church service, I had to stop and start 3 times to get it all on.  Pictures are great and easy to download software and upload the videos to computer. I haven't figure out yet how to upload to youtube, but working on it.

Reviews.Title: Sony Bloggie
Reviews.Author: Edward Stefanyak
Reviews.Content: By no means, I do not need something that's high tech. I do not need something that's new. I don't need or have time for something that's complicated.The Sony Bloggie is easy to use, small like a cell phone, and all I need is 4 hours of recording.My only concern is that it looks like HHGregg is no longer carrying this item. Does this mean that it's discontinued?

Reviews.Title: Good Video Camera for its kind...
Reviews.Author: Michael Torres
Reviews.Content: I checked so many reviews and video samples before deciding to buy this camera and I got to say I'm quite satisfied even with a few drawbacks.... Let's face it there's not a whole lot of choices for this kind of video camera out there , there's about 3 or 4 others and every single one of them has something that will make you cringe... Sony Bloggie doesn't support memory card which means once the internal memory is full you have to erase some to shoot some more and the battery doesn't come off as well so make sure to charge it before use... When I used my bloggie on my vacation trip I had to bring my laptop with me so at the end of every day I would upload all the videos to my laptop then erase it on my bloggie for the next day and the battery usually will last you all day even after shooting for 4 hours worth of 1080P ...I never had a day where we completely used up 4 hours worth in a day so memory and battery wasn't much of an issue for me as long as I can empty the internal memory on a regular basis... The HD Video looks sharp and the stabilizer works well, the only problem with this camera is that when you start shooting vertically you cannot turn it to the side (wide angle shot) without stopping it first or else when you upload your video it will be tilted since it doesn't automatically rotate the video if you shoot it in one continous motion (same with the iphones)... and just like most other pocket vid cams this one doesn't shoot well in the dark as well... My suggestion to everyone before buying a pocket vid cam, instead of looking for the perfect cam, try to find the most that will fit your need because there is not a perfect pocket vid cam out there yet.

Reviews.Title: Excelente
Reviews.Author: Dawniel
Reviews.Content: Excelente quede complacido con el producto, proximamente espero poder seguir realizando compras de este estilo, gracias por todo, Feliz Año

Reviews.Title: Nice
Reviews.Author: Trillmilk.
Reviews.Content: Pretty cool camera, I lost it. If this had a front facing camera this would be everything!! Definitely hard to record youtube videos with.

Reviews.Title: The problem is the battery
Reviews.Author: Rui Seixas Monteiro
Reviews.Content: I have this model, 8GB, the big problem is that the battery doesn't last long. Recording videos in 720@60dps is restricted to no more than 1 hour and 30 minutes, then the battery ends. I don't know if it is just my camera, but I don't think so. Another limitation is the so called 12.8MP still images, in reality the quality of those pictures is so bad, that 2MP is pretty all you need, more than this is pure waste of memory and time.BOTTOM LINE: A camera that advertises a recording time of 4 Hours and in reality deliveries 1:30 Hours, is to much deceiving to be acceptable!

Reviews.Title: What's up with the cracking noise!!!
Reviews.Author: K of The Midwest
Reviews.Content: I bought one of these to go on vacation and it works well maybe 6 times, after the use of those times,I made a video and I can hear a cracking or popping noise coming from the unit.This is not just on this one, I recently got my daughter one and hers does the same thing.This is a sony problem with this unit.It's great if you want a camera, but it's no good for using as a camcorder. I suggest you look into a flip or something else.While the touch feature is nice.I couldn't hear myself talk in the videos because of the popping noise.The HD is clear and awesome.The ONE and only problem was this awful noise.And if you look it up hundreds of people are stuck with the same problem.Again if you want a nice little camera feel free to buy it.But if you are looking for video skip it.

Reviews.Title: Sony Bloggie Video Camcorder MHS-TS20
Reviews.Author: Sree@Amazon
Reviews.Content: This product perfectly fits my requirement of taking many videos of soccer games my kids play. Also the built in bloggie software interface that gets downloaded to your computer allows you to share your videos to your youtube account.In terms of ease of use, it fits very nicely in your palm, and its really the size of any smart phone like Samsung, IPhone, Razr, etc.So this product has been an excellent value for money and especially the ease with which you can shoot many videos and transfer them to your PC.

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera for blogging!
Reviews.Author: joe9624 "Giuseppe Barletta"
Reviews.Content: I was able to get my hands on a Sony Bloggie Touch MHS-TS20 8GB model. This camera is perfect for the average day blogger hence the name Bloggie. It shoots videos in stunning 1080p and shoots still photos at 12MP.  The design of the Bloggie is absolutely beautiful! It looks like you are carrying an expensive piece of kit. I have the black color model shown above and it is like a brushed metal on the front with chrome around the lens. The camera has a 3 inch captive touch screen and only the recording button on the other side. The lens is a Sony Lens no Carl Zeiss or anything. Surprisingly though this camera takes pretty good photos and videos. The camera has a mini HDMI port on it so you can watch your videos and photos on the big screen. The camera has no physical zoom just digital but thats what you would expect from a camera this small. The image stabilization in this camera is amazing! I tried to take a blurry photo but it would not let me! My only real problem with this camera is how long it takes to auto focus while recording and the bad quality it has in low lighting. The only thing that was missing from this camera would be an led flash that would have been much better in dark situations (New Bloggie Cameras have this.). In general though this camera is perfect for what I need it for. Recording videos and taking quick photos on the go.

Reviews.Title: 1SG Hoover Says!!!
Reviews.Author: Robert W. Hoover "appliancebob"
Reviews.Content: One of the best cameras I  have ever bought, especially for the price.  I really use it and appreciate the quality.

Reviews.Title: Finally!
Reviews.Author: Phillip Kennedy
Reviews.Content: After years of messing around with all sorts of video cameras and coming up short, I finally have one that I can whip out of my pocket, click the on button and start taking videos of the grandkids.  Before, my battery didn't work, my disc was full, the doohickie wasn't snickerdoodling or whatever and I never got the video!  The ease with which this camera works is incredible!  Even a tech ignorant person like me can operate it and take great video and pictures without trying to memorize a 200 page operation manual.  Simple is better.  And the grandkids love watching the final result!  It's a winner!  and who would have thought I could pick one up for around $50.00.  Amazing!

Reviews.Title: Amazing video and FPS for the price for sports
Reviews.Author: Sports-Geek
Reviews.Content: I had been selecting a camera for quite some time for action sports footage and high quality scenery videos without having to pay a high price. The only things to keep in mind is, first: that the quality in low lighting is obviously not so great. Second, like many other reviews say, the auto focus is a bit laggy. I use the camera for filming underwater with a waterproof case and mostly for filming longboarding and skating sessions. The quality is amazing when the camera is well focused, if you are recording a quick motion like skating in my case, you need to give it some time to focus before you actually start recording or else the video will be somewhat blurry and you won't be able to tell when you watch it on the cam because the small screen always looks HD regardless.It can record amazing quality at 1080/30 FPS or at 720/30 FPS as well as 720/30FPS, great for slow mo editing.This camera is a great buy for the price and for its quality, it has yet to let me down and can compare to many professional cameras out there.

Reviews.Title: Amazing
